Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the background check amendment "outlawed any (gun) registry" when there are limitations and exceptions to the requirement.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or references to back up the statement that the amendment outlawed any gun registry.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the text of the amendment clearly and explicitly prohibits any gun registry, without acknowledging the potential loopholes or interpretations.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim as opponents of the amendment raised concerns about the potential creation of a national gun registry, suggesting that the amendment may not have completely outlawed such a registry.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the existing background checks require filling out ATF Form 4473, which includes personal information that is stored by gun dealers and can be inspected by the government in certain circumstances.
Understate: The claim understates the concerns raised by opponents of the amendment regarding the possibility of a national gun registry, suggesting that the amendment completely addressed and resolved those concerns.
